args.name: id
args.description: the id of the child object

obj.description: DEPRECATED IDs are used only to print the widget trees. To find a widget use `lv_obj_find_by_name` Get the child object by its id. It will check children and grandchildren recursively. Function `lv_obj_id_compare` is used to matched obj id with given id.
obj.returnsDescription: pointer to the child object or NULL if not found

obj.name: lv_obj_assign_id

args.name: class_p
args.description: the class this obj belongs to. Note obj->class_p is the class currently being constructed.

obj.description: Assign id to object if not previously assigned. This function gets called automatically when LV_OBJ_ID_AUTO_ASSIGN is enabled. Set `LV_USE_OBJ_ID_BUILTIN` to use the builtin method to generate object ID. Otherwise, these functions including `lv_obj_[set|assign|free|stringify]_id` and `lv_obj_id_compare`should be implemented externally.

obj.name: lv_obj_free_id
obj.description: Free resources allocated by `lv_obj_assign_id` or `lv_obj_set_id`. This function is also called automatically when object is deleted.

obj.name: lv_obj_id_compare
obj.description: Compare two obj id, return 0 if they are equal. Set `LV_USE_OBJ_ID_BUILTIN` to use the builtin method for compare. Otherwise, it must be implemented externally.
obj.returnsDescription: 0 if they are equal, non-zero otherwise.

obj.name: lv_obj_stringify_id

args.name: buf

obj.description: Format an object's id into a string.

obj.returnsDescription: current scroll position from top edge - If Widget is not scrolled return 0. - If scrolled return > 0. - If scrolled inside (elastic scroll) return < 0.

obj.returnsDescription: pixels Widget can be scrolled up before its bottom edge appears

obj.returnsDescription: pixels Widget can be scrolled right before its left edge appears

obj.name: lv_obj_get_scroll_right

obj.returnsDescription: pixels Widget can be scrolled left before its right edge appears

It means new memory will be allocated to store the properties in the destination style. After the copy the destination style is fully independent of the source and source can removed without affecting the destination style.

cache.name: lv_cache_create

args.name: cache_class
args.description: The class of the cache. Currently only support one two builtin classes: - lv_cache_class_lru_rb_count for LRU-based cache with count-based eviction policy. - lv_cache_class_lru_rb_size for LRU-based cache with size-based eviction policy.

args.name: node_size
args.description: The node size is the size of the data stored in the cache..

args.name: max_size
args.description: The max size is the maximum amount of memory or count that the cache can hold. - lv_cache_class_lru_rb_count: max_size is the maximum count of nodes in the cache. - lv_cache_class_lru_rb_size: max_size is the maximum size of the cache in bytes.

args.name: ops
args.description: A set of operations that can be performed on the cache. See lv_cache_ops_t for details.

cache.returnsDescription: Returns a pointer to the created cache object on success, `NULL` on error.

cache.name: lv_cache_destroy

args.name: cache
args.description: The cache object pointer to destroy.

args.name: user_data
args.description: A user data pointer that will be passed to the free callback.

cache.description: Destroy a cache object.

cache.name: lv_cache_acquire

args.name: cache
args.description: The cache object pointer to acquire the entry.

args.name: key
args.description: The key of the entry to acquire.

args.name: user_data
args.description: A user data pointer that will be passed to the create callback.

cache.description: Acquire a cache entry with the given key. If entry not in cache, it will return `NULL` (not found). If the entry is found, it's priority will be changed by the cache's policy. And the `lv_cache_entry_t::ref_cnt` will be incremented.
cache.returnsDescription: Returns a pointer to the acquired cache entry on success with `lv_cache_entry_t::ref_cnt` incremented, `NULL` on error.

cache.name: lv_cache_acquire_or_create

args.name: cache
args.description: The cache object pointer to acquire the entry.

args.name: key
args.description: The key of the entry to acquire or create.

args.name: user_data
args.description: A user data pointer that will be passed to the create callback.

cache.description: Acquire a cache entry with the given key. If the entry is not in the cache, it will create a new entry with the given key. If the entry is found, it's priority will be changed by the cache's policy. And the `lv_cache_entry_t::ref_cnt` will be incremented. If you want to use this API to simplify the code, you should provide a `lv_cache_ops_t::create_cb` that creates a new entry with the given key. This API is a combination of lv_cache_acquire() and lv_cache_add(). The effect is the same as calling lv_cache_acquire() and lv_cache_add() separately. And the internal impact on cache is also consistent with these two APIs.
cache.returnsDescription: Returns a pointer to the acquired or created cache entry on success with `lv_cache_entry_t::ref_cnt` incremented, `NULL` on error.

cache.name: lv_cache_add

args.name: cache
args.description: The cache object pointer to add the entry.

args.name: key
args.description: The key of the entry to add.

args.name: user_data
args.description: A user data pointer that will be passed to the create callback.

cache.description: Add a new cache entry with the given key and data. If the cache is full, the cache's policy will be used to evict an entry.
cache.returnsDescription: Returns a pointer to the added cache entry on success with `lv_cache_entry_t::ref_cnt` incremented, `NULL` on error.

cache.name: lv_cache_release

args.name: cache
args.description: The cache object pointer to release the entry.

args.name: entry
args.description: The cache entry pointer to release.

args.name: user_data
args.description: A user data pointer that will be passed to the free callback.

cache.description: Release a cache entry. The `lv_cache_entry_t::ref_cnt` will be decremented. If the `lv_cache_entry_t::ref_cnt` is zero, it will issue an error. If the entry passed to this function is the last reference to the data and the entry is marked as invalid, the cache's policy will be used to evict the entry.

cache.name: lv_cache_reserve

args.name: cache
args.description: The cache object pointer to reserve.

args.name: reserved_size
args.description: The amount of memory/count to reserve.

args.name: user_data
args.description: A user data pointer that will be passed to the free callback.

cache.description: Reserve a certain amount of memory/count in the cache. This function is useful when you want to reserve a certain amount of memory/count in advance, for example, when you know that you will need it later. When the current cache size is max than the reserved size, the function will evict entries until the reserved size is reached.

cache.name: lv_cache_drop

args.name: cache
args.description: The cache object pointer to drop the entry.

args.name: key
args.description: The key of the entry to drop.

args.name: user_data
args.description: A user data pointer that will be passed to the free callback.

cache.description: Drop a cache entry with the given key. If the entry is not in the cache, nothing will happen to it. If the entry is found, it will be removed from the cache and its data will be freed when the last reference to it is released.

cache.name: lv_cache_drop_all

args.name: user_data

cache.description: Drop all cache entries. All entries will be removed from the cache and their data will be freed when the last reference to them is released.

anim.name: lv_anim_speed_to_time

(LV_PCT_POS_MAX - LV_MAX((x), -LV_PCT_POS_MAX)) : LV_MIN((x), LV_PCT_POS_MAX)))) #define LV_COORD_IS_PCT(x)      ((LV_COORD_IS_SPEC(x) && LV_COORD_PLAIN(x) <= LV_PCT_STORED_MAX)) #define LV_COORD_GET_PCT(x)     (LV_COORD_PLAIN(x) > LV_PCT_POS_MAX ? args.name: rotation
args.description: clockwise angular offset (in degrees) from the 3-o'clock position of the low end of the scale; negative and >360 values are first normalized to range [0..360]. Examples: -   0 = 3 o'clock (right side) -  30 = 4 o'clock -  60 = 5 o'clock -  90 = 6 o'clock - 135 = midway between 7 and 8 o'clock (default) - 180 = 9 o'clock - 270 = 12 o'clock - 300 = 1 o'clock - 330 = 2 o'clock - -30 = 2 o'clock - 390 = 4 o'clock
